reviewText: I was late in discovering this movie, although certainly I was familiar with the title. In all honesty it doesn't surprise me that eating Mickey D's for 90 meals straight would be unhealthy. But I enjoy independent film and it took some chutzpah for Morgan to do what he did, not only in terms of taking on Goliath but also of challenging his own health. In the end it took him much longer to lose the weight than it did to put it on, but such cost did not come without reward: soon after the movie premiered, McDonalds got rid of the SuperSize menu (even though they won't admit there was any connection!).The commentary (with Morgan and his girlfriend, the vegan chef) is very fun and the bonus interview with Eric Schlosser is excellent.

reviewText: "Super Size Me" is Morgan Spurlock's funny/serious indictment of the fast food industry. Starting as a reasonably healthy and fit 30-year-old, Spurlock uses himself in an experiment to see how a constant diet of fast food affects people. He chooses to eat McDonald's food for every meal - breakfast, lunch and dinner - for a full month, much to the consternation of his vegan girlfriend and the growing concern of his doctors. Needless to say, the experiment does not go well. How badly it goes is the message of this movie.When "Super Size Me" isn't following Spurlock around the country - chronicling every meal, check-up and episode of vomiting - it teaches us about America's casual attitude to a serious health risk in our midst. Spurlock shows us that our children recognize fast food figures like Ronald MacDonald better than the president and religious figures. He graphically demonstrates the amount of fat and sugar hidden in fast food. He even introduces out to some way-out characters, like the man who eats up to nine Big Macs a day and stays pencil slim. "Super Size Me" shows us the way that fast food is marketed to kids on TV and at school, how its nutritional value is misrepresented by the industry, and how fast food chains cater eagerly to our insatiable desire for bigger portions of unhealthy food.Spurlock does go over the edge occasionally. I suspect that some of his bad reaction to fast food was due to his lack of experience with it. Going from strict beans-and rice diet to one stuffed with beef, starch, sugar and fat wouldn't agree with anyone's constitution. Still, "Super Size Me" ought to be a wake-up call to those of us who rely heavily on the fast food industry to feed our families and who are susceptible to the indestry's siren call for ever larger and ever less nutritious offerings. It should be required watching in all middle and high-school health classes.

reviewText: Morgan Spurlock is a genius!  For 30 days he ate nothing but McDonalds to see what effect it would have on his body.  With welcome doses of humor and science he made this film interesting, entertaining, and informative.  Not even his doctors predicted the consequences.Vomiting his first super-size meal, he Gained almost 25 pounds, and began to do serious damage to his liver.  Most vivid was his upset doctor informing him that the damage he was doing was similar to that of an alcoholic.  Each of his three monitoring doctors told him they found the results of his diet to be beyond their wildest expectations.  One passionately told him to stop, fearing permanent damage.  (In the end, it took him 6 months of healthy eating to lose all of the weight he gained in those 30 days.)In between meals, Spurlock did a wonderful job of reporting on the insidiousness of fast-food companies to infiltrate school lunchrooms and hook kids, guaranteeing future business.  Subtly slipped in here and there were hideously obese people patronizing McDonalds and working there.Also interesting was the bonus material of cut scenes and interviews, each of which could have been blended into the main film.  Of particular interest was the amount of garbage generated by McDonalds in a day: Enough to fill the Empire State Building.An eye-opening wake-up call.  Everyone owes it to their health to check this film out and make a commitment to eat better.  I'm going to make myself watch this once each month to keep me on the healthy track.  Truly amazing.

reviewText: I recently went out to eat with my girlfriend, not to McDonalds thankfully, and couldn't help but notice how many of my fellow diners were overweight. We're talking grossly overweight, too, not just a few pounds gained over the holidays. One family eating together at the next table over--father, mother, two sons, and daughter--was scarily obese. I probably wouldn't have noticed if I hadn't recently watched Glen Spurlock's scathing documentary on America's problem with the unwanted pounds, "Super Size Me," but the fact that I did notice nearly every person in this restaurant looked like a diabetes risk speaks volumes about the relevancy of this film. America has a big problem with obesity, a problem that various medical associations and watchdog groups claim will eventually lower the life expectancy for the first time in generations. In other words, the kids of today will actually live fewer years than their parents and their grandparents. Scary, isn't it? And Spurlock's documentary is just the latest to sound the warning bell on this troubling trend. That he does so with a sort of graveyard humor shouldn't take away in the slightest from the bottom line: America is fat and will pay a price for its libertine ways.Spurlock assigned himself a troubling mission: for an entire month he would eat at McDonalds. Every breakfast, lunch, and dinner would come wrapped in paper or cellophane topped off with French fries and a soda pop. Moreover, anytime the cashier asked Spurlock if he wanted to "super size" his meal, he said yes. Anyone who remembers a super size portion at McDonalds will understand what a daunting task this documentarian faced. Spurlock, convinced that a diet of nothing but McDonalds for a month would have some negative consequences to his well being, first went to a series of doctors to have his vitals measured. He returned to the physicians at various times throughout his little test, and the results were truly shocking. Not only did he gain weight, rather obvious considering his high fat diet, but other troubling problems arose. Most problematic was the result of double cheeseburgers and breakfast muffins on his liver. One of his doctors began issuing dire warnings about the state of his organ, claiming that if Spurlock continued on this path his liver might shut down entirely. Incredibly, Glen Spurlock continued chowing down all-beef patties and gallons of soda pop even when faced with such alarming evidence. True to his mission or stupid? You decide."Super Size Me" is much more than a mere document outlining one man's quest to prove that eating at McDonalds can cause permanent physical damage. Spurlock intersperses his jaunts to the local restaurant with interviews and road trips. He talks to Big Mac aficionado and all-around weirdo Don Gorske, who has eaten several of the huge sandwiches everyday for decades. He talks to a fitness coach named Phil Lawler about the dearth of physical education courses in today's schools. And he discusses the scurrilous effects of marketing junk food with supermarket guru Phil Lempert. We see our man visit a shop that deep-fries any type of food you can think of, from twinkies to chocolate bars. There is also a visit to a private museum consisting of nothing but McDonalds's memorabilia as well as a disturbing jaunt into a local school system to see what's on a typical day's lunch menu. I couldn't believe the junk kids at school can eat today! Wow! When I went to school in the 1980s we couldn't even have pop let alone various meals catered by local fast food restaurants. The highlight in my high school's cafeteria was spaghetti day, and the pasta was definitely not from a local restaurant.I enjoyed "Super Size Me," and considering that most of what we see here also appears in other documentaries about the dangers of excessive eating and the general lack of exercise currently plaguing the country, I don't think Spurlock is a propagandist. At first, I thought the documentary was going to be a hatchet job. Why? The presence of Spurlock's vegetarian girlfriend Alex Jamieson cast serious doubts on whether this would be an unbiased documentary. My concerns were laid to rest, however, when I learned that Alex is one of the most irritating individuals I've seen in a film and when I saw that Spurlock didn't totally buy into her ideas of what is or isn't healthy to eat. In fact, Glen comments quite frequently that he likes the food at McDonalds. Obviously, there are people who will say that "Super Size Me" is a muckraking documentary and will never accept evidence to the contrary. They have a point in that Spurlock singles out McDonalds for special attention. What about the danger posed by Burger King, Pizza Hut, or a number of other big fast food chains? I think it is safe to assume that these restaurants pose the same sorts of risks, and I would like to see more about them.Pay attention to the special features on the DVD. An interview with Eric Schlosser, author of the now seminal "Fast Food Nation," calls attention to some aspects of the fast food industry missing in the documentary. I wasn't particularly enamored with Schlosser's book when I read it three or four years ago, but he does have some important insights to offer here. Too, a feature called "The Smoking Fry" will definitely have you wondering what the heck McDonalds puts into its French fries in order to keep them fresh. Apparently, plastic isn't the only substance that will never break down into its component parts. I heartily recommend "Super Size Me" to anyone who eats fast food more than once a week.
summary: Entertaining even as it delivers scares

reviewText: After watching this documentary, I can't help but wonder if the newer, and healthier, menu choices at McDonald's are a result of the director's findings.  Not only will this movie get the viewer to think about nutrition and fast food, but it will get the viewer thinking about exercise.The documentary follows the director as he decides to quit exercising and to eat nothing except foods purchased from McDonald's.  Of his self-imposed restrictions, he can't eat the same thing until he has tried all the items on the menu, and if he is asked to super-size the meal, then he will do so.  Throughout the film, he speaks with doctors who monitor his progress.  The doctors, and we the viewers, are surprised at the results (although we could figure out the weight gain).This movie will make you think about your own nutritional choices.  If this documented experiment doesn't, then the pictures of the food slowly degrading will.  I would recommend this movie to fast food junkies everywhere.
Title: N/A

reviewText: This documentary has it all:  chock-full of research and facts, it is presented in a light-hearted and engaging manner.  I picked this up after hearing a lot of the press, and I expected to be following director/star Spurlock around as he ate McDonald's food three times per day for 30 days.  I was pleasantly surprised to find that his journey and the resulting film offers much, much more than just a story about a man who eats a lot of junk food.  Spurlock's journey is the glue that holds together a film that features many facts about diet and exercise, interviews with experts and industry insiders, a look at how fast food is marketed to children, a look at the school lunch industry, and much more.We all know fast food is bad.  Spurlock's three doctors who monitored him before, during, and after his little experiement knew it was bad.  They just didn't know how bad.  They didn't realize they'd be begging him to stop his silly experiment because it was ruining his health at a rate they never expected.  This is eye opening for anyone who thinks fast food is "bad," because the truth is a lot deeper than just that.Are people right to be suing the fast food industry for their health problems?  Spurlock does not answer that question, but he gives you a lot of data for you to make up your mind.  Prepare to have your eyes opened!Now that this film has made it through the circuit and it out on DVD, time has passed, and we can see the impacts.  McDonald's no longer offers their menu items in "super size" (this happened 2 months after the film came out, but McDonald's denies any connection).  With the raised awareness, people started looking for alternatives to fries, and McDonald's now offers fruit and salads as combo meal alternatives.  Let's hope that we've hit rock bottom and the changes continue to come, so that in 25 years this will be a picture of "the way we were."The DVD extras are definite must-sees.  There's a quick one about the garbage produced by the fast food industry, but the aboslute winner is "The Smoking Fry," which will make you really wonder what is inside those McDonald's fries.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Six weeks after this film aired at Sundance, McDonald's eliminated super sizes. What more is there to know? America's addiction to fast food is a complex social phenomenon, inadvertently caused by the interstate highway system, women working in large numbers post-WWII, TV and the growth of mechanization in every business--to mention just a few. Obesity is complicated, but there's no question that taking in more calories than you use is cause. Morgan Spurlock in this film and "Fast Food Nation" told us something we all knew.This film is pretty gross, to put it mildly. Just looking at the food made me feel queasy--imagine eating it all the time! Spurlock's medical team never imagined the damage that the food would cause to his body, and it took a lot longer than a month to reverse. The most telling part of the film for me was simply watching the expressions on Spurlock's face as he grew lethargic and depressed, then hyper after eating. His skin went from normal to dull and almost grey. And the weight--25 lbs. in a month. A wake-up call for everyone!
Title: N/A

reviewText: I re-watched this film after viewing a pathetic attempt at a rebuttal in the cheaply made "Fat Head".  I honestly wanted to see what made the filmmaker so upset that he felt the need to eat fast food for 30 days to prove Spurlock wrong.This film is just a million times better.  The information is much more comprehensive and Spurlock interviews several people who disagree with his point of view.  Any well made documentary has got to include some counter-point or it just comes across as preachy and is quickly tiresome.  In this film he interviews several industry lobbyists and fans of McDonald's.  My favorite subject is an eccentric man who has eaten at least two big macs a day for years but still appears to be in excellent health with a cholesterol level of only 140.  Spurlock could have tried to mock him or make him look foolish but he seems to actually like the guy.  He just lets him speak without much commentary, which is another sign of a well made documentary."Supersize Me" is somewhat sensational but so is most fast food advertising.  The food lobby is not exactly powerless to the big bad government as the other film would lead you to believe.
summary: Fairly obvious information but presented in a highly entertaining way!

reviewText: So what's he trying to prove?  That if you overload on crap food for a month, it will harm your body?  DUH!!!  This was not a documentary, it was a propaganda piece.  If you eat 5000 calories of any food, you're bound to have negative effects.  Why pick on McDonald's?  There's enough junk fast food places that share the blame.  My biggest complaint is where they show him vomiting and becoming delirious.  First of all, you gulp down 40oz of a sugary drink on top of two Big Macs, vomiting is a foregone conclusion.  Second, you wouldn't become delirious due to food, unless the food was tainted and you developed sepsis or a fever, or you have diabetes and or hyperglycemia.  Otherwise, it was all acting on the part of the movie maker.  This movie is a bigger load then the one I lay in the toilet after eating 20 piece chicken nuggets.  Check out "Fat Head" for a more unbiased documentary on the topic.

reviewText: Well, yes, some of the previous reviewers are correct,  "we already knew that."  And I already knew that---about McDonalds Food, that is.  But, for me, it never hurts to have someone remind you of something that you "already know"---to bring it once again to your attention---in a very convincing manner.  After all, here's a guy who weighed 180 or so pounds and in 4 weeks he's up to 205 with high cholesterol and a "fatty liver" just because he ate McDonalds burgers and fries!This film is a good reminder for all of us.  And, there is some useful "information" in the film that I didn't know....such as the "school food company" that uses "real food" to feed the kids  at a certain school and seems successful in promoting good food habits.  We can use the experience of this school as an example for the schools near us.  And in another instance in the film,  there's a school for "problem students" who were put on a "real food" diet at lunch time and their behavior "calmed down" as a result of the change in diet!Yes, perhaps like you,  I also was skeptical about "the value" of this film and I thought I "knew it all" but I did learn things from this film.....and it was a good reminder for me----thanks for the reminder.  As a result of this film,  I guess I'll avoid buying McDonalds and just stick with Burger King !  :o)  Email  Boland7214@aol.co

reviewText: Props to Mr.Spurlock & everyone involved w/ this movie. I admired him for sticking it out the complete 30 days even when there was pressure from his doctors to end this experiment prematurely. What a terrific eye opener for this great country. It's obvious there is a serious & growing obesity problem in America. The solution is simple I think, we need to change the way we eat & get active, make time to exercise! Don't support companies like the fast food industry, not just McDonald's alone, that feed us processed garbage that eventually leads to obesity and other health problems related to their foods, including shorter life spans nationwide! I'm buying this movie after renting it soley because I want to support this cause. The message and lessons learned from this movie need to be heard. It's not a joke, obesity is a very serious issue and it will only get worse unless people are educated and start making changes for the better. I also loved the deleted scenes, extra interviews, and the "smoking fry" was hilarious! What the F***'s in those fries? It's not from earth, haha. This documentary has changed the way I look at foods forever, it educated me, and I am eating healthier now because of it, no more fast foods, frozen foods, candy, ice cream, doughnuts, & sugary sodas/cereals for me. Lastly, as a new parent I'll be teaching my kid to eat healthy as well... SUPER Size that!
summary: the documentary every american should see

reviewText: Notwithstanding a veiled reference to reduced sexual function as a result of this lethal diet, the film is a timely and appropriate object lesson for us all, and most especially, for our kids. Spurlock's clever side commentaries on McDonald's history and the problem of obesity in America are every bit as informative and alarming as the daily spectacle of watching him pack on pounds and come dangerously close to liver failure. "Supersize Me" is never preachy and doesn't have to be: Spurlock's transformation speaks volumes in itself.

reviewText: 30 days of nothing but McDonald's food sounds like a lark & perhaps a little foolish. Morgan Spurlick surmised that he would need more to make a movie & filled out his dvd with plenty of extra footage. By the 20th day of nothing but Micky D's food, he was dying. I was shocked. To me on an entertainment level this was way better than any action movie. This was real & immediate. He did have some rules. He had to sample at least once every thing Mickie D had to offer. He'd supersize only when asked. He would try to eat three times a day. Wisely, he had a good support system. He employed a number of medical specialist. Most important of all was his girl friend. She must really love him. They were all concerned that he might not make it to 30 days with out some really bad medical complications. He had to give in at one point switching to water instead of other beverages. This was permissible as Mickie D sells bottled water.Boomers have been eating this stuff most of their lives & in massive quantities it is so ubiquitous. Not just McDonalds but Burger King, Hardees & all the thousands that follow the leaders. They are not evil & we all have free choice.  But we are killing ourselves a centimeter at a time.  An excellent movie on a now very public problem, not fast food itself but it's abuse, aftermath, in health probelems & obesity.

reviewText: What is going on here? This film isn't just about the insanity of eating McDonalds three times a day for thirty days, and it doesn't just portray a jackass stunt. It's not an angry polemic against America either. It's about medical evidence, dietary evidence, evidence about who runs what in America, and it's about irrefutable trends across specific demographics, including children. It's got facts. It's got doctors. It's got nutritionists. It's got circumstantial evidence that any moron can put together to conclude that fatty and sugar-infested fast foods are dangerous and have a negative effect on people who eat them. I guess some people are very angry at this documentary (such as food industry lobbyists in Washington) because they realize that the information presented here, in a compelling and funny manner, is going to remove dollars from their wallets and lower their stock prices. So what do you do if you're a lobbyist and someone is attacking your revenue stream? You kill the messenger, of course, or label him a liberal or some other totally irrelevant thing. One of the most telling facts I learned was that Congress passed legislation (!!) in May of 2004 making it ILLEGAL to sue fast food restaurants for causing ill health. Illegal!! Can you imagine that? Who was behind that, I wonder? Vegans? Legislators with our general health interests in mind?Super Size Me is a great documentary. Every parent and every consumer of MacDonalds and all the other fast food garbage out there need to see it to understand how these corporations are ripping off our bodies, our minds, and our wallets. Amazing!
Title: N/A

reviewText: This was an interesting, entertaining, and ultimately sad look at the way Americans eat. But it really wasn't any big surprise. Frankly, the only surprise for me was that Morgan Spurlock's weight and blood counts weren't *worse* after a month of eating only McDonald's. After watching it, I wasn't certain what the intended point of the documentary was. To tell us that we live in the most obese country in the world? Most of us already know that. Was it to tell us that McDonald's doesn't serve healthy food? Anyone that's within a hair's breadth of sanity knows that already. Ultimately, while I did enjoy it, I felt that this was a shockumentary, and upon reading that Spurlock was denied into USC's film school five times, I have a better understanding of why he may have made the film. How better to get yourself on the map than by doing something so quietly disgusting?The interview with the author of Fast Food Nation was the best part of the DVD, and it's the only reason this review gets three stars. If I were to rate this on the movie itself, it's a one star review, two at best. I could have spent ten minutes on McDonald's website, looking at their nutritional information, imagined what life would be like if I ate their food for thirty days, and envisioned exactly what I saw in this film.

reviewText: Morgan Spurlock conducts an "experiment" on McDonalds food resulting in conclusions that have no scientific validity based on the fact that he violates almost all the guidelines of the scientific method. None of the outcomes should be taken seriously, only as a matter of entertainment. For more information read about proper experimental control, dependent and independent variables, spurious relationships, and the scientific method.

reviewText: A "4 x 4" is a quadruple cheeseburger (4 meat patties, 4 slices of cheese) sold off-menu by a burger chain well known in the SoCal area, a semi-surreptitious transaction reminiscent of the whispered come-on, "Hey, mister, want to buy some dirty pictures?", of a long-ago, less liberated era. I'm salivating just thinking about it - with fries, of course.SUPER SIZE ME is an absorbing and informative documentary ostensibly targeting McDonald's as the purveyors of nutritionally nasty food that's undermining the foundations of global health. Writer/director Morgan Spurlock volunteered himself to eat nothing but McDonald's fast food for thirty consecutive days while having his physical health and blood chemistries monitored by medical and dietary professionals. Morgan had several self-imposed "rules". He had to eat all three daily meals at the chain, consume every item on the Golden Arches menu at least once, and agree to "supersize" his order if asked by the sales clerk. Morgan sampled outlets across the U.S., including California, Texas, Ohio, and New York.By Day Thirty, Spurlock had gained 27 pounds while driving his liver enzymes, cholesterol, and triglycerides levels up into the heart palpitations range. But, over and above documenting this personal self-abuse, Spurlock mainly examines the effects of fast food on the nation's young - the insidious insinuation of the stuff into school lunch programs, and the wickedly pervasive advertising by the evil fast food giants designed to hook children for life before the inevitable triple bypass. The documentary visually reinforces the message with shot after shot of grossly overweight citizens both behind and in front of the McDonald's cash registers.For all its slick presentation, one is left with the unanswerable question, "OK, so now what?" Do governments - local, state, and federal - pass laws prohibiting the sale of the classic cheeseburger/fries/Coke meal? And what about pizza, my own personal favorite that I'd eat three times a day - with a fried chicken chaser - if I could get away with it? Haven't we already tried that approach with alcohol, drugs, prostitution, and porn? And those crusades went well!While I personally love greasy fast food, and fantasize doing a side-by-side taste comparison of the locally available cheeseburgers all in the space of a day, I prudently don't indulge more often than once every two weeks. Perhaps it comes down to an informed personal responsibility, self-respect, and a wife that makes me eat my veg, rather than the need for a Nutrition Gestapo, which is perhaps an extrapolation to be favored by bleeding hearts after viewing this admittedly Oscar-worthy film.SUPER SIZE ME will either make you weep for America's future, or bring a smile to your face as you contemplate the futile idiocy of certain causes. Either way, it's provocative entertainment.
Title: N/A

reviewText: As strange as it may sound, most of America is being poisoned by a repulsive clown and his goofy henchmen. And what's more, Ronald and co. certainly don't want you to know about it.This film is an at times disturbing, at time hilarious look at what's making this country so flippin' fat. It's the gigantic portions of junk that passes for food from fast-food restaurants. Being a vegan, I felt, even before watching this, that I had dodged a major bullet with regard to the inherent health risks in eating this way. After watching Super Size Me, I wanted to send a copy of this film to everyone that I care about.Morgan Spurlock decided to eat an all-McDonalds diet for an extended period of time, in order to see what possible adverse health risks could develop. What happened was worse than what the experts predicted. He gained a lot of weight, and his cholesterol level skyrocketed. Apparently, he even feared continuing the diet due to the results of being a Big Mac Junkie.The film also discusses how public schools are being infiltrated by fast-food (which is an indictment on that industry, as well as the failure of local, state, and federal government), and it shows how, by adopting a healthy menu, school's can still remain fiscally solvent.Super Size Me demonstrates how fast-food chains manipulate children by offering toys, playgrounds and cartoons, as well as the unholy marriage between fast-food and Corporate America. The interview with the industry lobbyist is very telling.The extras are very interesting, too. If you've ever wondered how long it takes for McDonalds fries to decompose, the answer might shock you! There is also an interview with the author of Fast-Food Nation, which, incidentally, is the perfect companion to Super Size Me.Let's wake up and slim down America. We can start by watching Super Size Me.
summary: Would You Like Fright With That?

reviewText: Morgan Spurlock's entertaining documentary attack on corporate America, focuses on the fast food industry in general, McDonald's in particular, and their relationship to American's health in general and obesity in particular.  This young man documents his month of eating three meals a day at McDonald's.  He visits three doctors, a dietician, and a trainer regularly and begins in excellent health.  The doctors foresee no problem with his plan, assuming he will probably increase his cholesterol somewhat.  But after two weeks they become concerned for his wellbeing and advise him to stop.  He completes the month 25 pounds heavier, with much higher cholesterol, a compromised liver, suffering heart palpitations, mood swings and depression, and addicted to fast food's sugars and fats.  It takes him nine months to recover his previous weight and overall health.  It's one thing to know that fast food is bad for you, quite another to see it demonstrated.
Title: N/A

reviewText: The idea of this film intrigued me from the start.  A man decided to eat McDonald's three meals a day for thirty days.  He did so because of the rather absurd claim by the McDonald's Corporation that their food could be part of a healthy diet.  With the aid of three doctors and a nutritionist, Morgan Spurlock embarked on this diet in order to see the effects it would have on his body.  After 30 days, Spurlock gained 25 lbs, doubled his cholesterol and triglycerides, not to mention the fact that he began to show signs of liver failure.  Of course, this is not enough to create a whole feature film, so Spurlock spends time exploring how fast food has entered our schools and how they have lied about or tried to hide the health content of their food.  This is a great film although it does hae a hint of bias that a true documentary would strive to eliminate.  That should not take away from the fact that the film does have an important message that should be taken seriously.  The only thing that this movie has working against it is that, for me at least, it's not a film that I would need to see more than once or twice.  After that, it just doesn't have the entertainment value to make you watch it over and over.
Title: N/A

reviewText: ...to warrant the 4 stars.  I see many reviews referring to the bias inherent in this documentary.  Yes, it's biased--the creator was motivated by the problems that giant, gloabal corporations and brand marketing have created for average people.  If you look at the first few minutes of this film, you should immediately think of Schlosser's "Fast Food Nation" or Naomi Klein's "No Logo." In my view this bias (wanting to inform and motivate normal people) motivated me to watch the film, so I was fine with it.Here's the heart of what Spurlock is trying to show--McDonald's is spending MILLIONS of dollars to convince people that the way of life it represents is wholesome and family friendly.  By setting up play structures and advertising with clowns, McDonald's and other fast food chains actually outflank parents in their efforts to feed their kids healthy food.We should all understand that (a) no physician would ever advocate what Spurlock tried, nor would they see his activities as a model of "normal consumption" for others, and (b) those reviewers who claim that individuals need make smart choices about what they put in their own bodies are right.  But do these two assertions imply that (a) average people aren't consuming too much fast food, or that (b) all of the reasons for their consumption are within their control?Here's my take: think of the daily choice to (not) consume fast food as an exam.  In school, when an instructor administers an exam, (s)he expects a normal distribution of results. If the final grades are distributed normally, (s)he can therefore conclude that the scores the students earned relfected their talent, preparation, and motivation.  If instead, 90% of the students  fail the exam, the instructor would ask questions. Was the exam biased? Were my teaching methods effective? Were the testing conditions fair? Etc. If the instructor concludes that the test was biased for some reason, (s)he would likely toss those results, and give a new test INSTEAD OF JUMPING TO CONCLUSIONS ABOUT THE STUDENTS. To go back to fast food: if so many people are becoming obese and experiencing other health related issues in direct correlation with the growth of the fast food industry in this country, is it _possible_ that there may be some factors outside of their control that are influencing their choices? And if these factors do exist (advertising, product placement, taste engineering, etc.), would it be worthwhile to address them in some way?Schlosser and Spurlock are basically arguing the same thing: Fast food's marketing practices create an unhealthy and unfair environment for people making choices about consuming fast food. In Spurlock's case he literally shows you some of the possible harm of overconsumption by subjecting his body to a month of McDonald's (he's got more courage than I have, I'll admit). He goes from a guy who literally can't hold down a supersized meal (yes--you see the full technicolor yawn when he tries to eat a double qtr-lb'r meal), to a guy who can't give it up. Hopefully his experiences will help counter-balance the effects of much of that marketing. It's gross, but effective. And personally, I found the comments by his girlfriend about their...intimate relations to be strong motivation to stay out of McDonald's!But the true treasure on the DVD is Spurlock's interview of Schlosser. It's like witnessing the formation of the "Justice League". Just watching these two bounce thoughts and experiences off of each other was incredible.  In retrospect, had I seen this interview, and discovered that the movie itself was damaged, I still would have rated this DVD 4 stars.See the film for yourself.  And while you're watching, ask yourself, "what is this crazy man REALLY trying to tell me?" The answer may involve a LOT more than your health!
summary: The Interview with Eric Schlosser is enough...

reviewText: If you want to stop eating McDonald's or French fries, this is a film for you. Morgan Spurlock took a great idea and ran with it. It is very entertaining.

reviewText: We watched this DVD in college a couple of times.  Then, the Dr.'s office where I was working started showing it to their patients.  I now own a copy and share it with my friends.  Don't think McFast Food can kill you?  Honestly!  Watch what happens when this guy eats McDonald's "healthy" food.  Think your diet soda, McSalad and McFruit cup is healthy?  Find out the truth from McDonald's info on this DVD.  The truth hurts, but it is better to see it and live than miss it and die. (NO JOKE!)Great info!  Well documented!  Presented in a very entertaining manner.  More than just McDonalds in this DVD.  Great information about what our school children are being fed by the government!  Ever hear of "dumbing down the population?"  This video may help save your student's grades and future!  I highly recommend it to everyone.  Be aware that there is some crudity and graphic scenes which really get the point across but may not be suitable for young children or more sensitive viewers.Oh, yeah!  Just for the fun of it:  If you LOVE McDonald's, go get your favorite meal deal and enjoy it while you're watching the movie.  It might be the last fast food you will ever want to eat!

reviewText: Entertaining, shocking and horrifying details follow and the viewer gets an education that may inspire some serious rethinking of what is allowed on said viewer's table. Well worth the time investment.Super Size Me inspired my family's love of quirky documentaries. (Super Size Me is also joined by the classic Best In Show Mockumentary on our list of favorites.) Though we first saw Super Size Me a few years ago it is in our DVD library and we have watched it several times. And our youngest daughter used Spurlock's findings in a recent term paper.Though this documentary was just the beginning of our awareness of what you eat can kill you, Super Size Me made a lasting difference in our lives. Now bad choices in food are still guilt-ridden but Spurlock's experiment and the knowledge that came from it helps us to avoid mindless eating. This documentary was fascinating from a medical and psychological standpoint and entertaining, too. The extras are worth watching.

reviewText: What an incredible film!  In order to put a human face on the epidemic of obesity, which is fast becoming one of the nation's biggest killers and is contributed to in a major way by fast food, Morgan Spurlock decides to eat nothing for 30 straight days but McDonald's food.  There are two rules to the experiment:  he can eat ONLY what's on McD's menu, and he must take supersize orders whenever the cashier asks him if he "wants that supersized."  At the beginning of the 30 days, he has all his vitals checked by a number of health professionals, including a cardiologist, gastroenterologist, family practitioner, and a diet specialist.At the end of the experiment, he's gained 30 pounds and his liver is backing up on him.  He feels and looks like crap, and all of the medical people monitoring his health tell him that he's killing himself.  It takes him almost a year to detox.The obvious point is that fast food is a killer.  Granted, very few eat as much of the stuff as Spurlock did during his 30-day binge, but most people admit to eating the stuff more than once a week.  Diet experts interviewed in the film argue that even this is way too much.  The simple fact is that fast food portions are getting larger and larger, fat and sugar and sodium is higher and higher, butts and bellies are getting more and more bloated, and arteries and livers--you don't even want to know.One of the most frightening aspects of the film is the hold that McD's has on the nation's youth.  Two scenes in particular suggest how effective McD's advertizing machine is.  In one, primary school kids can identify a picture of Ronald McDonald, but not Jesus or George Washington.  In another, a chorus of school younsters are singing a stupid but influential jingle over and over:  "Pizza Hut, Pizza Hut, Kentucy Fried Chicken and Pizza Hut!  McDonald's, McDonald's!"  When they get to the "McDonald's" part, they form the golden arches with their hands.  And who says that advertizing to the tune of billions of dollars isn't effective?Watch this film, read Eric Schlosser's _Fast Food Nation_, and swear off profit-driven mcfood groups.
summary: Your basic  Mcfood groups:  sugar, salt, fat

reviewText: Ahhh, the good ol' Big Mac theme song.  I've always loved it.  I've also been very fond of the sandwich it describes.  As a matter of fact, I enjoy a lot of things on McDonald's menu.  "Super Size Me" introduces us to the ugly side of those loveable golden arches and that friendly-faced clown spokesman they call Ronald.  Morgan Spurlock goes on a diet most of us fat folks would love to be put on in this documentary which sets out to show us how bad Mickey D's and fast food in general really are for us.Spurlock goes on an all McDonald's diet for thirty days and, surprisingly, his health and mental structure turn into mush.  Spurlock has an interesting and fun way of providing us with the dark truth.  Just watching this guy cram a Filet-O-Fish into his mouth and gulping a super-size Coke is rather hideous.  We see him go from a fairly fit human being to one of us(us being the good fatties of the world).  His condition does become potentially deadly near the end of his diet, but I think that is because he(being skinny in the beginning) didn't allow his body to evolve into the well-oiled(or just plain oily) machine that is a fat person.Though some of the information is disturbing to learn, there really is nothing new here.  I believe that it's pretty safe to say that most people already knew that fast food was bad for them.  This movie merely puts the numbers in front of our swollen guts.  Spurlock does show how many of these fast food chains have infiltrated the public school system and also gives us a good explanation on how much money these companies plunk down for advertising.I'm giving it four stars because it is interesting to watch, and Spurlock is a likeable fellow.  I especially enjoyed his adventures in Texas, the state that boasts some of the fattest cities in the U.S.  I guess things really are bigger in Texas!  (Before I get any nasty comments, I really love Texas.  It's my second favorite state behind my home of Louisiana.)As stated before, there isn't much here that hasn't been said about fast food.  Also, common sense should tell you that this stuff isn't that healthy, but it tastes sooooo good.Rent it before you buy it, it might be a little too honest for some.P.S.  Five stars to the Big Mac.  If lovin' you is wrong, I don't wanna be right.
summary: "Two All Beef Patties, Special Sauce, Lettuce, Cheese..."

reviewText: Images from the TV spew out millions of commercials each year and many of them are in regards to high sugar, high fat and high cholesterol foods.  These commercials use happy and playful themes often directed towards children, which raises the question do the children purchase these food items?  Why would big multibillion dollar companies aim there attention to the children of today?  Could it be that they are interested in investing in the adults of tomorrow?  Why is it that these companies have high sugar, fat, and cholesterol in the food items they advertise and sell?  These questions are answered in Morgan Spurlock's documentary Super Size Me, which is an in-your-face depiction of the unhealthy food that is sold through many of the fast food restaurants throughout America.The McDonald's spokesman has said that it is possible to eat responsibly at McDonald's, and the food has what is required for a balanced nutritional diet.  Despite this, America has turned out to become the fattest country in the world where obesity has lead to an avalanche of cardiovascular disease, which has become one of the major killers of American citizens.  Morgan Spurlock decides to bring on the multibillion dollar corporation McDonald's and see if what the company says is true.  The purpose of choosing McDonald's as the fast food eatery is that they have far more eateries around the world and in America than any other fast food chain.  Thus, Morgan says lets bring them on by eating three meals a day at the golden arches establishments for 30 days.Before commencing the one-tracked McDonald's diet Morgan does it with a scientific approach as he visits with three different doctors where two are specialists in fields related to what happens in the body when food is ingested.  Morgan also visits with several professionals in the field of exercise and nutrition in order to get proper measurements of the body prior the McDonald's experiment begins. The conclusion that all of the involved parties get from examining Morgan before the Mickey-D's diet is that he is in good health and above average physical condition.  In order to control the experiment Morgan decides that he should be as American as possible, he also researches how much daily exercise the average American acquires, which is about 5000 steps per day.Throughout the 30-day journey of ingesting only McDonald's the audience is to follow Morgan, as he gains approximately one pound per day.  In addition, Morgan begins to suffer from several different side effects from the diet such as high increases in blood pressure, cholesterol increases above what is recommended, skin changes to an unhealthy look, mood swings,  lack of energy, chest pains, drastic changes in sex life, and liver toxicity.  Despite these negative physical, psychological, and social affects he reminds the audience that he feels better whenever he ingests another meal from McDonald's.  This gives an indication similar to the one of heavy drug users feel when they have been on a drug and the body requires a new fix in order to return to what feels like a bodily equilibrium.There are several moments when Morgan visits with his doctors and professionals who are amazed by the negative influence the McDonald's diet has one him.  They all urge him to stop the diet, and warn him if he feels in certain ways that he must call 911, or seek medical attention at once.  One of the doctors is amazed that this high fat diet affects the liver in the same way that heavy alcohol abuse does over a prolonged time.  Nonetheless, Morgan endures to continue his experiment, as he seems determined to finish what he started.During negative affects of the McDonald's diet Morgan ventures throughout America where he visits schools where he addresses the poor nutritional diet while also displaying the positive change in an Appleton, WI, school for troubled kids where the employees noticed a significant change when they moved to a well-balanced organic diet with no pre-made meals or soda.  Morgan meets with kids whom he quizzes on if they know who the person on a picture is, and most kids did not know who George Washington was while immediately they recognized Ronald McDonald and Wendy's Pippi Longstocking looking character.  There is also a scene where a man who used to drink enormous quantities of soda is about to have a surgery to reduce the size of his stomach  This man tells his story, as he recalls a moment when he lost his vision at work, which was directly related to ingesting the large quantities of soda as he has developed diabetes.  Interchanging between interviews and visits Morgan jokes by talking directly into the camera about how he is feeling the affects of the McDonald's diet.Super Size Me is documentary that should have been done fifteen years ago, but it is better late than never.  The film is not an attack on only McDonald's, but corporations preying on society and future generations by encouraging them to eat poor nutritional diets through high sugar, high fat, and high cholesterol foods.  This is in a society where physical education has drifted into the back seat of spending more time reading and doing math.  Not that reading and math is not important, but actual research has provided insights that physical activity promotes neural connections in the brain, which speeds reactions and cognitive processes.  In disregard to such research Physical Education has fallen behind, as the American society seems to have gotten denser and fatter.  Physical education could also teach students what to do at home after school and later in life to maintain a healthy lifestyle, which could help cut massive amounts of dollars lost due to illness related to inactivity, obesity, and poor nutrition.Super Size Me raises a number of questions such as why have long-term goals been often forgotten and only quick solutions are targeted, e.g., prepping for test scores and not learning for knowledge and wisdom? Should math and reading be taught at the expense of health?  Should organizations that have an interest in profiting from the American population by decreasing its overall health be allowed to lobby in Washington, D.C. and other places?  As this documentary points out, more is not better.  Maybe society needs a little time to find a good middle ground where the future of America can restore its health and academic achievement for future generations.
summary: Fast Food - Weight Gain - Health Problems - Brilliant!

reviewText: There is a psychological axiom which far too few truly embrace: No one can make you feel (bad) but you. Starting with that foundation, it is far easier to appreciate this movie for the data within. Whether or not the director is trying to push some personal agenda, there is a good deal of excellent information to be gleaned. While the scene from the initial consumption of a super-sized meal may have been staged, I don't think it is outside the realm of possibility. I don't mind admitting that it's my favorite scene in the movie. I think it encapsulates the film quite effectively- be it gratuitous or not. I also think it is absolutely hilarious and presents an enlightening message to the viewers.Many have questioned the director's motives. However, I believe that these arguments are completely irrelevant. If you're sufficiently enlightened to cast judgment then you should likewise be savvy enough to accept the information in the context under which it is provided. I think the director is rather forthright in his presentation of the subject. There's a lot to be had here. The subject is presented clearly enough that anyone with above a room-temperature IQ should be able to see through any claimed subterfuge.A great many arguments have been proffered regarding the conditions under which this "experiment" was performed. However, I don't feel that the author has hid any material factors. If the author's goal was to address every possibility he'd never finish writing the script. I think he did a great job with the subject. I think the fact that he was in good health to start with was invaluable to the message. I mean, the guy put his health on the line and all we can do is find fault?The bottom line is that there is a great deal to be taken from this movie. I believe the information is presented in a very entertaining and engaging way, and I certainly thank (rather than curse) him for that. I'd much rather learn from an entertaining and/or impassioned teacher than from an automaton.

reviewText: Movies come out all the time that are intended to change the world, such as Michael Moore's "Fahrenheit 9/11" that tried to affect the outcome of the 2004 presidential election. However, rarely does a film succeed in changing things the way this little movie did and contntinues to do so.By now you must know this movie is one filmmaker's personal journey through fast food America, living for 30 days on McDonald's and "super sizing" every meal when requested. His health deteriorates and he is a changed man 30 days later, a testimony to the changes fast food has wrought on America.While this film brought great respect and admiration to one filmmaker, it did far more -- it changed the way American fast food operates. In effect, "SuperSize Me" coalesced three forces in American society and brought them immediately to the attention of the public and boards of directors of America's fast food delivery agents. Those forces are:-- A staggering increase in the levels of obesity in American children.-- A growing knowledge that most poor children receiving national health care, or Medicaid, eat French fries almost every day.-- Warnings by offialdom in American government to change the dietary habits of newborns and children, leaning out the fat and loading up on vegetables and other nonfat foods that aid growth and development.These events all coalesced around the release of this remarkable little film, which did more than anything in history to document the nutritional failure of fast food and its "super size me" culture. Even though the company denied it, there was no coincidence that McDonald's went to a healthier menu immediately upon release of this movie and now aggressively promotes healthier alternatives in its food offerings.The rest of fast food America gathered in lockstep and followed the giant's lead by adding salads, carrots and other low fat high nutrition menu items and recommending replacement of French fries as their staple food item.We all owe enterprising filmmaker Morgan Spurlock a great debt of gratitude for exposing unnutritional American habits in a way that is funny, entertaining and interesting. This movie grips you from the very beginning and doesn't relent, all the time entertaining while exposing. The DVD offering includes extra footage on the changes in fast food culture that double the message of the movie.Here is indeed a moment in time when pop culture America changed health America in a very positive way. This is one of the best uses of cinema since the eight-hour "Shoah" exposed the lingering feelings of some Germans about the Holocaust.

reviewText: It's not often that Documentary films get the recognition and publicity of the big theater releases, but "Super Size Me" is one that did.  The reason for this is that on the surface, it touches a topic that in one way or another hits just everyone - McDonalds.  I think one way or another, McDonalds Restaurants impact us:  whether we like the food;  whether we detest the food;  whether we see another restaurant at every intersection and street corner; whether our children beg us to go there; or whether we are just sick of their advertising - McDonalds seems to hit close to home.  Another key element to this documentary is the Director Morgan Spurlock - who also is the Narrator and a Subject of the film's investigation.  Spurlock not only brings an interesting topic to film, but also uses his personality to make this an interesting and entertaining film to audiences.On the surface, the premise of this documentary is that Morgan Spurlock is going to look at the impacts of eating nothing but McDonald's food for a period of 30 days.  Spurlock shows how doing this has had a negative impact on his body.  Before embarking on the experiment, Spurlock consults with medical doctors, a dietician, and personal trainer and is assessed in perfect health and fitness.  During the course of the film, we see how Spurlock will undergo both physical and mental changes.  The physical changes include a rapid weight gain, headaches, cholesterol  increases, and an increase in fat in the liver.  We see mood swings and a decrease in energy by Spurlock.  However, this study is basically one way to further investigate a deeper topic - Obesity.The topic of Obesity seems to be something that Spurlock is looking to gain attention.  It is pointed out that Smoking and Obesity are the two top causes of preventable death.  There is a lot of comparisons  done to the Tobacco industry.  The Tobacco industry has gotten a lot of publicity in recent years in regards to the impacts it has had on society. There was a lawsuit against the Tobacco Industry on the impacts that Tobacco and Smoking have had on people.  Spurlock does an excellent job at starting the movie by mentioning the lawsuit that two people filed against McDonalds on the negative impact of the film.  Spurlock pointed out how the Judge in that case said if the two people can prove that there is a direct tie to McDonalds food, then they have a claim.  This becomes the premise of Spurlock's experiment.The way this film was constructed is very good.  As mentioned, Spurlock opens the film with the McDonalds Lawsuit- and this becomes the basis for his experiment.  We are then treated to a very entertaining chronicle of Spurlock's experiment.  This is where Spurlock himself becomes a key part of why this documentary is good.  Spurlock isn't a tight and stiff doctor or scientist and he isn't a stuffy filmmaker - he simply comes across as an everyday guy.  What is nice is that he is going to tell the story in his own words - and he interjects the right sense of humor at the right times.  Interspersed between the experiment are several periphery topics related to Obesity and the Fast Food industry.  These informative topics include:  The Lawsuit Itself; a look at "Super Sized" Fast Food portions; Impact of Obesity on Health Problems; and a very entertaining short animation of Chicken McNuggets.There are also some other topics interspersed that are clearly worth mentioning.  He looks at the impacts of obesity and nutrition on the younger generation.  He discusses how not just the fast food industry, but how Candy Companies and Cereal Companies target their marketing audience toward youngsters.  This provides a nice segue into how children are getting nutrition outside the home (i.e. school).  Spurlock does a nice piece on looking into School Nutrition and how some of these programs are as tainted as the Fast Food Industry itself.  Spurlock will look at a how one food company is contracted with a lunch program that is also used in the prison system.  He will also look at how a Federal USDA Program also drops the ball in terms of nutrition.  Finally he will look at one school that is doing school lunches "the right way".There are some other highlights:  Spurlock's attempts to get "interviews" with the corporate hoods at McDonalds; Spurlock's attempt to locate nutritional information at many of the McDonalds; Features that include comments from John Robbins of Baskin-Robbins Ice Cream, Jared Fogle (the Subway Spokesperson), and Eric Gorske (who has eaten 19,000+ Big Macs in his lifetime).  There is also an interesting twist to the story - Spurlock's girlfriend is a vegan chef. It's entertaining how she reacts to the whole experiment.I also like how Spurlock takes us on a cross-country journey.  While the experiment starts and ends in New York City - Spurlock takes us to Los Angeles, Texas, Illinois, and Washington D.C.It's hard to say how accurate an experiment Spurlock conducts in this film.  Basically you are going to have to take the word of Spurlock himself and the doctors in this film.  Spurlock does set up some ground rules for the experiment that he has to abide by - and he does seem to follow them. While we know that Spurlock is doing this for his meals, what we aren't told is how Spurlock is handling his mid-meal snacking.  Is he still eating McDonalds food in-between meals?  I'm also wondering if he did target certain meals to create a true month-long "fast food" binge.  While I do raise these questions, I am not disputing many of the facts that Spurlock brings up in this film.  He raises a lot of interesting points and brings them to the forefront.Overall, this is an outstanding and entertaining documentary.  This is one to be watched many times over.  Highly recommended.

reviewText: Actually the cover shot of Morgan Spurlock with a load of McDonald's french fries crammed into his mouth is a picture of the writer-director of this 2004 documentary taking good care of his health.  That is because when you watch the bonus features on the DVD version of "Super Size Me" the last one is a look at "The Smoking Fry," which strongly suggests that the other thing beside cockroaches that will survive a nuclear holocaust might be the french fries they serve at McDonalds."Super Size Me" follows Spurlock through a thirty-day period in which he eats nothing but food served at McDonalds.  The research question is what happens to an average adult American male when he sticks to this sort of a diet.  Spurlock has a team of doctors and nutritionists who detail exactly what happens to him, and let me just say by way of understatement that very little of it is good (eating food to avoid headaches could be considered a good thing).  In between the three visits each day to McDonalds (except when Spurlock has his food delivered), the documentary explores the history and the psychology of the American love affair with fast food.  One of the documentary's sub-plots, as it were, is a lawsuit against McDonalds claiming it is responsible for the obesity of two teenage girls.  That lawsuit inspired Spurlock's grand experiment, and I cannot help but think that according to the American legal system the worst thing McDonalds has ever done was serve hot coffee.The camera shows Spurlock at the low points of his odyssey, from the rectal exam and the vomiting brought on by eating an entire super sized meal in 5 minutes, to his girlfriend critiquing the changes in their sex live and the doctors who try to talk him out of continuing his "diet."  In addition to what it does to Spurlock's body, the most damning evidence in "Super Size Me" comes from the simple evidence that we are living in a fast food culture.  Adult Americans might not know the Pledge of Allegiance, but they can sing about what you get in a Big Mac.  Even little kids know who Ronald McDonald is, even if they have no idea who is the guy Spurlock is showing them that is NOT George W. Bush.  This is not a high tech documentary and Spurlock never really gets the chance to confront a spokesman from McDonalds to spring a Michael Moore-like trap.They say that McDonald's cancelled its "Super Size" program in the wake of Spurlock's documentary, and it would be nice to think that there is a causal link here.  But when you consider that during the 30 day period Spurlock was only asked if he wanted to super size his order six times, the better explanation might be that McDonalds could not get its own employees to support the program.  When you look at some of the deleted scenes and other interviews you realize Spurlock could have gone overboard on his indictment of McDonalds and fast food (the McDonalds Project is a great example of how wickedly funny social art can be), but clearly in the end what it did to his body as he ate in 30 days the same amount of fast food that the average American consumes in 8 years, is enough to do the trick.You will not want to eat as McDonalds as often after you watch "Super Size Me."  Some people will be convinced never to go back again, but I suspect most people will at least me compelled to think twice.  I rarely go out for fast food, not because I am health conscious, but because when I spend money on a fast food meal I keep thinking that I could have bought a really nice steak instead.  A stop at McDonalds is something we usually do when we are on the road and traveling great distances.  I remember when we came back from Europe having to stop at McDonalds to eat a Big Mac because that is what America tastes like, and with that deep thought I will leave you to mull over the attendant ironies.
summary: This if Morgan Spurlock.  This is Morgan Spurlock on Big Macs

reviewText: Watching this documentary is about as fun as eating fast food.  Sure, maybe it's a bit of a stretch to be so harsh with McDonalds after going out of his way to abuse their food so long, but there's something irresistably fun about seeing the filmmaker actually become the documentary in addition to filming and narrating.  It also impressed me that he would do so much damage to his own health to make a point.Actually one of my favorite parts of the DVD was the bonus feature where various burgers and fries were put in glass jars to see which ones would decay the most quickly.  If I remember correctly, the McDonalds fries were still "fresh" after several weeks had passed, which makes one wonder if there's anything organic in them at all!  Ha ha.I personally don't have anything against McDonalds, and I don't want them to go away, but certainly the message is at the very least "all things in moderation".  What better way to illustrate this than by throwing moderation out the window and following food addiction to its logical conclusion.

reviewText: By far this was the most stupid documentary I've ever seen and I'm shocked that its received so much attention. This was just an unfair attack against McDonalds. His agenda was to see if in fact by eating McDonalds for 30 days, if he would get health problems, gain weight, etc... Duh. But here's my problem with the guy. At the beginning of the film we obviously see that he is in tip top shape. The man has perfect blood pressure. He's at the right weight for his height. He works out regularly. He's just in perfect condition. During one of his first few meals, he ate his first supersize combo meal. I say his first because thats the impression he gives the viewer. He's completely in awe of the size of the French Fries container and the double quarter pounder. He proceeds to eat. 10 minutes later he feels ill. He's exhausted from eating the "large" meal and then we actually see him vomit! What a drama queen! Give me a break! Anyway, although other name brands of fast food, fatty foods and sodas are mentioned, the main target is McDonalds and I am so ticked at this guy acting as if people are forced to eat that food. One question he asks the viewers is why should french fries be the only option for a side order? I got an answer to that one. If you don't like what's served or how its prepared, eat somewhere else! What really irked me is when he brought kids into the equation and how McD's really targets them with their happy meals and playgrounds. He did actually take a step away from McDonalds and attack the schools for not giving children a better lunch menu, but like I said, most of the film is centered on Mickey D's. Hey I got an idea. How about we go after birthdays and blame whoever started the tradition of eating cakes and ice cream?By the end of the film, the man offered no solution. He leaves us with the impression that overweight Americans have no personal responsibility for their weight problems. Basically, we have this health nut along with some of his doctors telling people we shouldn't eat McDonalds. I don't know about anyone else, but I never ate McDonalds thinking I was eating healthy. Stop making the obesity problem a complicated issue. People are fat because they are lazy, they don't exercise enough, they make poor food choices and eat too much. It's common sense. What makes a person fat or why they continue to remain that way is an indivual problem that cannot simply be solved by holding a fast food company or any corporation responsible. It's called personal responsibility, people. Some choose to smoke. Some choose to drink. Some choose to over-eat and eat the fatty foods. I for one am glad we live in a country with choices.
Title: N/A

reviewText: Common sense seems to be one of those things that many of us takes for granted, that many of us believe that society as a whole exercise their right to choose based on common sense. GUESS WHAT! it is not so. Today more than ever, much of society has given up their capacity to free choice to somebody else. Many people wants others to think for them because self responsibility has become too much of a frightening burden to endure. This way, if something goes wrong we can always blame somebody else. The food industry (among others) has done just that, mesmerizing us with -bigger is better- mentality and quantity over quality (including monetary cost) is all that is important. Many of us have imbraced this way of thinking because is easy to follow than lead (and that is the reason I mentioned above). Should be common sense that fast food is bad food and should be eaten in moderation (perhaps no more than twice a month), but who has the time, or will to cook at home today or do anything ourselves anymore? we are (as a whole) a lazy society and we are paying the price for it with our own lives. We must understamd that it is our own fault for the food industry unhealthy overall products, but we give them the power to do so by not making up our own minds about it and putting and end to this madness. Of course many, many sector of the industry today are adopting this quantity over quality mentality simply because that is what people wants, look at the car industry for example or the media mindless eye candied programming today. Unless we regain control of our choice, unless we stop and say no!, we are only destined to spiral down into the abyss of chaos. I don't mean to be this negative, but if you look at the way the world is overall today and stop sugar coating things, you will probably see that, unless we change our self inflicted vanities, there will be no light at the end of the tunnel. Overall: VERY GOOD!
summary: Great point about overall common sense!

reviewText: This DVD has added material, but not just non-nutritive stuffing. There's a surrealistic interview with a couple who collects McDonald's memorabilia and an introductory analysis of how a supermarket's layout is designed to sell certain foods (guess which ones).There's a consideration of  the deep-fried Twinkie- a subject that scarcely belongs with food at all and a completely revolting section on composting McDonald's.The additions turn this into more of a complete essay on trash food, although the viewer still ends up yearning for a bit more organization and an argument more complex than 'eeeyuuu, this is gross'.The five stars reflect the film's groundbreaking narrative. It challenges a now-engrained folk habit by turning it into a way of life and in the process making it look more than ridiculous.A must-see for everyone concerned about how we eat and how the sense of taste is disappearing even as food television becomes more popular.Lynn Hoffman, author of New Short Course in Wine,The and the nutritious and delicious bang BANG: A Novel

reviewText: Super Size Me is the now (in)famous story about a man who eats McDonald's food every day for a month. Can you guess what happens? While it is entertaining I did feel the conclusion was obvious. In my opinion, McDonald's is a fast-food restaurant like any other and no one who eats out everyday does it for health reasons. Spurlock seems to grind his axe at times and almost seems "anti-corporation" which rubbed me the wrong way. I get the impression he is trying to remove the individual's right to choose since every individual has a responsibility to themselves regarding healthy eating and living. Perhaps the documentary is directed towards young people who were never taught the basics of food education at home. He does make some good points while disgustingly showing the lack of decomposition of fast food. This is the educationally enhanced version which includes 61 minutes of new, instructional content and games that help educate viewers on a host of subjects related to the film. Honestly, if you haven't seen the documentary yet I would just get the original DVD (theatrical release) sold separately for less money because the enhanced content doesn't add much value to the viewer nor does it include the original supplements which are superior (4 deleted scenes, interviews and an audio commentary). The DVD has managed to hold its value.This Educational DVD features: 24 Curriculum Lessons (12 Middle School Lessons, 12 High School Lessons), Super Quiz Me Game, Cafeteria Counter Activity, Student Handout Materials, Instructor's ManualCurricula Includes: Behavioral Studies and Life Skills, Health, Language Arts, Math Applications, Physical Education, Science, Social Studies
Title: N/A

reviewText: I highly dislike McDonald's. No, wait. I really find McDonald's disgusting! I used to feel that way before I saw "Super Size Me". But the movie actually super-sized my feelings about the world's biggest chain of bad food there is.As strongly as I feel about them, when the lawsuits against them came out I couldn't help but feel that they were a bit frivolous, by not acknowledging the level of responsibility that we all have as individuals for what we put into our bodies. But worse than the lawsuit was the way it was dismissed, which was beyond laughable, putting the burden of proof on the people who sued McD, by partly saying that they had failed to demonstrate that the food McDonald's served was unhealthy.... Just see the movie, and you will be able to decide for yourself if this makes sense or not.At the end of the day, the disappointing thing that becomes patently obvious after you see "Super Size Me" is that the consumer's health and best interests are not typically at the top of the agenda of the food industry as a whole, and social responsibility is a concept that seems to elude them when the interests of the shareholders and Wall Street expectations start to knock on the door.What do I think about "Super Size Me"? It is a great documentary that puts the facts about this critical issue on the table, in a balanced way (actually attempting to incorporate McDonald's comments into the movie, without success). Hopefully a heads up and a call to action: watch what you eat and don't entrust your health to the food places. They owe allegiance to their owners, not to consumers.
summary: My feelings towards McDonald's are super-sized!

reviewText: There was SO MUCH hype over this film, I think I was expecting something much more professional. I know I was expecting to love this film, if for no other reason than because I am a vegetarian. But my reaction to this film ended up being rather ho-hum.First of all, the premise of the film was gimmicky. I didn't know Spurlock's experiment consisted of eating nothing but McDonalds -- no vitamins, snacks at home, water at home, etc. That's stacking the deck. Also, my husband and I were baffled by the sheer amount of food he ate -- he ate enough for two or three people. That wasn't exactly the scientific method. And where in the world did he get the money? Who funded him? It seemed almost shady, in a way.Then, I saw the frat paddle on his wall. To me, being a frat boy and being a subversive, counter-cultural filmmaker -- well, they don't exactly go hand-in-hand, now do they?Some of his medical facts were wrong. He claimed that polycystic ovarian syndrome is CAUSED by being overweight. Uh .... no. POV CAUSES weight gain and CAUSES patients to become overweight. He had it backwards. Maybe because it is a women's health issue?I thought the graphic design in the movie was shoddy. Also, for heaven's sake, that awful, awful artwork his friend made ... ugh. Also, the original music for the movie was terrible, like bar band music. These elements gave this film the feel of an undergraduate student project. Not that there is anything wrong with that, in and of itself, but the way this movie was touted as being soooo IMPORTANT -- I expected a lot more!I felt at times that Spurlock was really into blaming overweight people for being overweight. I also felt he discriminated against handicapped people. I especially did not like the shot of the overweight person using the motorized store wheelchair, and Spurlock's comment that "people in America don't like to walk." Well, it's a little hard for a HANDICAPPED person to walk, dontcha know? It has nothing to do with laziness and eating at McDonalds. That shot was just plain rude. And, I know quite a few "overweight" people who eat healthy diets and work out. I even know some "overweight" vegans. Spurlock should have addressed the fallacy of the BMI chart and how healthy bodies can come in all shapes and sizes.The more I think about it, the more I think this movie was just a flash in the (hamburger) pan. I doubt we'll be hearing much from this filmmaker again. The topic of the film was worthy, but the execution left much to be desired. It sure wasn't worth all the hype it got. Rent it, get it at the library, buy it used  -- don't waste your money buying this new.
summary: Not as good as I expected

reviewText: Morgan Spurlock's documentary - in which he consumes nothing but McDonald's food for a month in 2003 - is funny, cleverly produced, and somewhat alarmist.  It's not good science, but does offer some interesting social commentary on the power of the fast food/commercial food industry and is one man's rather striking video exercise in culinary self-abuse.  The personalities (girlfriend, medical/nutrition folks, people on the street) were interesting.  Most importantly to me Spurlock makes his point without being unnessarily mean.  His various asides were also quite good, especially his forays into what public school systems can do to more responsibly exercise their in loco parentis duties as they care for our children.

reviewText: Super Size Me is a fun, interesting, and somewhat disturbing documentary about the fast food corporation, mainly targeting McDonald's, but exploring plenty of different aspects, including the so-called food served in high school. It is a riveting portrait if there ever was one, about an insane man's quest to prove that McDonald's does in fact cause obesity. His task was quite ridiculous since anyone who eats McDonald's three times a day for that amount of time will no doubt gain some weight, but the film itself was well-made and quite engrossing. This is a film everyone should see, although now, the whole No Carb diet is getting quite ridiculous, and America might go even more health conscious after this (or was this what caused it?) Not sure, but either way, I was entertained, I was terrified, and I was extremely glad I saw this. If you missed it in the theaters, give it a chance on DVD or Video. It's a good way to spend a Sunday afternoon.

reviewText: Morgan Spurlock is trying to show us that eating too much fast food can be harmful to our health and causes obesity, but I don't think he went about it in the right way.  He ate nothing but McDonald's food for 30 days (all 3 meals).  Who does that?  It's not the same if you eat a fast food meal once in awhile (say once or twice a month).  I also don't see his point in his rule that he had to supersize everytime he was asked, and especially his rule that he had to eat everything he bought.  The way I see it, you eat until you're full, and then stop.  No one should force themselves to keep eating after they're full.  That's ridiculous!  No wonder he threw up out his car window!  Fast food is like everything else.  It's not the same in moderation as it is when you go to extremes with it.  I agree that there's a real problem with obesity in this nation, but we can't blame it all on fast food.  People eat too much period.  This film is an eye-opener to the problem with obesity, but it's not a very realistic way to go about proving the causes of it.
summary: I don't really agree with the way he went about it!

reviewText: Michael Moore had nothing but good things to say about Morgan Spurlock's film and that should be taken as a positive note. For 96 minutes, the viewer is taken into Spurlock's analysis of `fast food' and although it is all what you would expect, it still has some gross surprises. The public has always held a fascination for people who subject themselves to being guinea pigs to prove a point and Spurlock proves his "theory" successfully. How many people slow down to see a car accident? It is entertaining with some obvious revelations that don't necessarily take away from the story. I doubt people will stop eating McDonald's food completely, but this is certainly a worthy documentary. The additional interview by Eric Schlosser, author of "Fast Food Nation" is a great extra. No story can be told perfectly without an additional perspective.
